To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged, as if the voyage were commending at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibralter, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Malls arrive Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
The Sea Fares are:-
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT ALEXANDRIA, (Kom-el-Nadours. Observatory.)

Mercury is invisible at the beginning of the month, and becomes a morning star by the middle of it.
Venus is morning star throughout.
Mars starts about 9._0 p.m. throughout the month.
Jupiter is visible all night.
Saturn sets a little after 10 p.m. at the beginning of the month and a little before at the end.

div.head: RUSSIA TO-DAY.
div.p:
What has happened in Russia, what it happening, and what is likely to happen form the components of a problem. The sudden resolution of any constituent elements, like the subsidence of some huge structure of masonry, must always be accompanied by a vast amount of destruction through the mutual concussion of its various parts. What we are witnessing in Russia at the present moment is not so much revolution,
which implies arms and a leader, as the violent disintigration of an impossible union of anta- gonistic and ill-assorted materials.

Therefore, we have had bloody massacres and even battles in which people, bureaucratic agents, intellectuals, industrials, revolutionists, sailors, soldiers, socialists have been engaged in almost indiscriminate destruction, inspired, amidst the sudden strophy of centralised government, either by predatory lust or by an anthusiasm for the particular social or religious theory they have adopted and made their own. And, remmeber, there is not in the wide world a more fanatical theorist than the half-educa- ted Russian. There would be a better prospect of the emergence of a Liberal Constitution if the various elements of disorder were in rough and ready agreement with one another. When, however, the political and economic machinery of the empire was suddenly put out of gear, the shock threw every one off their mental and moral balance, and while the Government cannot cope forcibly with the new tactics of the revolutionaries, and re-establish the status quo by arms, there is not sufficient revolu- tionary cohesion for an encounter, corps a corps, with the still concrete fact of bureaucratic reaction.

Nevertheless so much has been gained that a fire has been kindled which, although it may smolder, can never be put out. The revolution has discovered a power before which all the force of Tsardom is important. And even should chaotic extravagance of thought and action and lack of cohesion conduce to a temporary check of the Liberal movement and the withdrawal or nullification of the privileges obtained, it has amply proved the temper of its weapons, and can look with confidence to the future.

Now, it is precisely for this smouldering of the fire that the bureaucratic power has been watching and waiting, trusting for ultimate salvation to the stomach to drive the revolu- tionary spirit of the great strike movement back to the paths of subordination and wage- earning labour.

In the forefront of bureaucratic oppression, the influence which, like a heavy stone impos- ed upon grass, has for many generations dwarf- ed and stunted the moral and material deve- lopment of the Russian people, has been the foreign ambition of their masters. In the inte- rests of these they have been sacrificed, rob- bed bled; and the prospects of genuine reform are inseperably bound up with the inaugura- tion of a moderate, unambitious, and economic foreign policy which, on the basis of good rela- tions with all, will permit the fullest concen- tration of national energy on the moral and economic regeneration of the race. What is happening in Russia to-day is no more than a reflection of what took place in this land of Egypt several thousand years ago; and the Pharaoh of the Neva will prove as obdurate of heart as his prototype of the Nile, until, in the fulness of time, the fire- which naught can quench- will burst forth once more, with furious finality.

It has been frequently asked whether, and to what extent, the Russian peasantry have been affected by revolutionary teaching and principles. This is a very material question, because until the Russian proletariat is ready to think, speak, and act in unison there can be no revolution, in the fullest sense of the term. At the present day, however, there is no material for a Jacquerie- and if active revolution is to come, and the events of the last few days at Sevastopol look as though it has come with a vengence, it will be brought about by a revolt of the sons of the people in the armies of the Tsar.

div.head: COUP D'ETAT IN RUSSIA. GRAVE EVENTS AT TZARSKOE SELO. THE END AT HAND FINANCIAL PANIC. (Gazette's Special Service)

div.p: Things in Russia are undoubtedly going from bad to worse. There are rumours to-day that a great coup d’etat has taken place at St. Petersburg, and large numbers of Cossacks are said to be assembling in the Capital.
A great run on the savings banks through- out the country is taking place, and there exists a general financial panic.

Reuter's Agency learns from St. Petersburg that the attitude of the Government is consi- dered as suicidal, playing into the hands of the revolutionaries. Financial and commercial circles are aghast. There was a further heavy drop in prices both at St. Petersburg and at Moscow yesterday. It is openly declared in the Bourse and elsewhere that the days of the present regime are numbered.
(Reuter)

When the garrison of Fort Peter and Paul assembled for roll call, the artillery demanded the immediate release of the electrical students arrested on the 29th November. This demand was transmitted to the Commandant of the fortress, who complied.

It is officially confirmed that the loyal troops have captured the barracks occupied by the mutineers at Sevastopol. 2,000 of these with quick-firing guns have surrendered. The cruiser Otchakoff is gutted, but is still floating. The town is not damaged.

A number of Guardsmen have been arrested at Tzarskoe Selo for presenting demands ob- jecting to being obliged to act as police. It is reported that the mutineers at Sevastopol have regained the upper hand.
(Reuter)

It is rumoured that a Grand Duke partici- pated in a plot against the Tsar. There are some indications of conspiracy of the officers of the Guards, but it is impossible to say defi- nitely whether any Grand Duke participated. Officials, however, admit the reports of grave events at Tzarskoe Selo.
It is understood that the whole Cossack forces of the Empire will be mobilised.
(Reuter)
Martial law has been abolished in Poland.
(Reuter)
Martial law in Poland has been removed.
(Havas)
It is believed that to-day the Cabinet decid- ed upon resigning without dissolving.
It is understood that Mr. Balfour will see the King early next week, The Radical papers now intimate that Sir Henry Campbell-Banner- man is prepared to accept office if the King desires him so to do.
(Reuter)
The Algesiras conference has been put off till January.
(Havas)
The Assize Court has acquitted the prisoners accused of the attempt made on King Alfonso's life on May 31.
(Havas)
M. Jaluzot will appear before the Correc- tional Court on the 28th inst.
(Havas)

div.head: Ghezireh Palace Hotel,
div.p: This hotel will open on Sunday, 10th inst.

div.head: The Mahmal Guard.
div.p: The Ministry of War has decided to send the Redif whose term of military service will expire in January next, to act as the guard of the Mahmal.

div.head: H.M.S. Carnarvon.
div.p: On leaving Alexandria next week the Car- narvon is expected to go to Patras, Platraes, and Corfu, returning to Malta (whence she came) on the 22nd inst.

div.head: Oxyrynchus.
div.p: recommence Messrs. Grenfell and Hunt, who have been staying at the Hotel du Nil, Cairo, are shortly proceeding to the Fayoum to recommence their excavations at Oxyrynchus.

div.head: Suex Canal.
div.p: Fifteen vessels passed through the canal on the 28th and 29th ult., of which 8 were British, 4 German, 2 Dutch, 1 Austrian. The total amount received in dues from the 1st to the 29th November was frs. 9,333,997.14

div.head: Minet el Kamh Court.
div.p: A correspondent writes to complain of the disgraceful state of the Native Court of justice at Minet el Kamh. The building is old and dilapidated and surrounded by malodorous birkets and native huts of the lowest descrip- tion.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: From the 1st of January to the 30th of November 985,669 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. Wales sent 531,639, Newcastle 221,413, Scotland 118,203, Yorkshire 74,373 and other places 40,041 tons. During the corresponding period of last year 979,309 tons were received.

div.head: Provincial Anglican Services.
div.p: To-morrow, the first Sunday in Advent, there will be a Litany and High Communion at 11 a.m. at Mansourah and Evensong at 6.30 p.m. at Tantah. The complete list of Anglican services at Mansourah and Tantah during the month will be published in an ap- proaching issue.

div.head: A.L.M. & D.S.
div.p: We are asked to remind our readers of the lecture to be given at St. Andrew's High School on Monday next by Dr. Ruffer, C.M.G., on "The Desert of Sinai." The lecture will com- mence at 9 p.m. and will be illustrated by about 60 lantern slides. A large gathering is expect- ed, as many tickets have been disposed of.

div.head: New Khedivial Hotel.
div.p: This evening the new "five o'clock tea" will be inaugurated at the New Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria. The Tsigane band will play a charming selection of airs. This combination of tea and music, which promises to be a favourite fixture with Alexandrian Society, may be enjoyed daily during the winter season.

div.head: Cairo Tramway Co.
div.p: Eighty new cars are arriving in Egypt before next February for the Cairo Tramway Com- pany. Each car is fitted with a first-class compartment and a harem. Next week the company will begin the new line from the Cairo station to Zaptieh. The extension of the Boulac line to the railway workshops will also soon be begun.
H.H. the Khedive has been graciously pleas- ed to confer the rank of Lewa on Captain McMurdo, Director of the Slave Trade Repres- sion Department.

Count de Vanvineux, French Commissioner to the Caisse de la Dette, is expected to return in a few days to Cairo. The Count passed the summer at Invernsch in Scotland and has been staying in France since the middle of Sep- tember.
Count Antoine de Zogheb returns on the 18th inst. The Countess de Zogheb will not return to Cairo till early in January.
The Rev. John Watson (so well known under his nom de plume Ian Maclaren) and Mrs. Watson left Cairo yesterday morning, and intend to make a short stay in Sicily.
The Hon. F.G. Morgan, American Vice- Consul-General, and Mrs. Morgan are spending a few days at Mena House.
Lieut. Col. Ludlew, A.S.C., late D.A.A. and Q.M.G. at Alexandria, as assumed duty at Cairo as officer commanding the A.S.C. in Egypt.
M. Anders, dragoman of the German Diploma- tic Agency, left Alexandria yesterday for Mossoul (Mesopotamia), where he will open a new consulate.

The following passengers left Cairo on the 1st inst. by P.S. Hatasoo for the Nile trip:- Mr. J. Sonneborn, Mr. A. Fischinger, Mr. A.P. Stewart, Baron Dr. Anton Koblitz, Dr. Anton Janiczek, Miss A. M. Harsant, Mr. C.B. Harsant, Mr. P.O. Cassidy, Mr. R.D. Bingham, Mr. J.E. Bingham, Mr. J.L. Low, Mrs. Low, Mr. M. Sanchioni, MMr. B.T. Hammond, Mr. D.F. div.head: THE SUCRERIES MEETING OF CREDITORS.
div.p: The meeting of the creditors of the Societe des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte, postponed from Thursday last, took place yesterday at the Mixed Courts, Cairo. At 3.15 p.m. Judge Tuck opened the proceedings by stating that he had received communications from cultivators in Upper Egypt hoping that the Sucreries Co. would continue to exist. He then read a letter which he had received from the directors of the Sucreries Company, who criticized the last report of the experts on two grounds-firstly, the though it had been agreed that a copy of the report prepared by Sir William Willcocks, Fourneron Bey, and Professor Sampaolo should be put into the hands of the board of directors 48 hours before the meeting of creditors convoked under the concordat preventif, the members of the board were not, as a matter of fact, supplied therewith, and were in consequence compelled to hear its criticisms in silence, unable to offer a prepared defence. The criticisms of the ex- perts who had two months' time to prepare their attack reached the public, through the medium of the press, unbalance by the defence which the directors would otherwise have been in a position to offer. Secondly, they protested against the excessive animus that marked the criticisms passed on the administration of the company by the three experts.

Judge Tuck, in reply, stated that on the first occasion when the report was to be read, the three experts found themselves unable to complete it in time to deliver a copy to the representatives of the Sucreries Company forty- eight hours before the meeting of the creditors took place. The legal representative of the company was warned but demanded no post- ponement. No engagement was entered into the delivery of a copy forty-eight hours in advance on any later occasion.

The Judge then called upon M. Zigliara, the clerk of the court, to read the correspon- dence that had arisen re the letter written by Me. Fatica and addressed to Judge Tuck on the subject of the Ibrahimieh Ploughing Company. The correspondence consisted of the experts' answer to Me. Fatica and a com- munication from the board of the Sucreries Co. on the same subject, with a covering letter from the Hon. A.J. Davey.

The correspondence having been read Me. Carton de Wiart mentioned the results of the Sucreries shareholders' extraordinary general meeting of the Saturday last and stated that certain further delays in the acceptance of the proposals made under the concordat pre- ventif were inevitable owing to the appoint- ment of MM. Letort and Cozziks, who were to study these proposals and watch the nego- tiations connected therewith on behalf of the shareholders at Paris and at Cairo respectively. These gentlemen had not been as of yet able to come to an entirely satisfactory arrangement with one another and the board would not be able to bring its proposals before the court till Monday or Tuesday next. He in conse- quence asked for a postponement during which the verification of the claims of the creditors could be made or at least begun, and the meeting was in consequence adjourned till Tuesday and Saturday next.

div.head: MACHELL-GLEICHEN MARRIAGE.
div.p: The marriage of Countess Valda Gliechen and Mr. Machell will be quite a small affair and the King and Queen are to be present with other members of the family. As the apartments of Princess Victor Hohenlobe- Langenburg are so small, many of the Countess Valda's friends will be invited to a reception which is to take place in the Armoury of St. James' Palace on the day before the wedding. Countess Valda's real names are Victoria Alice Leopoldine Ada Laura and she adopts the name of Valda from V.A.L. Ada.

Mr. Percy Wilfrid Machell is the son of the late Rev. Canon Machell and the Hon. Mrs. Machell, of York. On the death of his uncle, the late Captain Machell, he succeeded to the old family property of Crackenthorpe, in West- moreland, which was in the possession of his family at the time of the Domesday Book Deeds and family records show direct descent as Lord of Crackenthorpe from 1246 until the property sold in 1786 by Lancelot Machell, elder brother of Colonel Machell, Mr. Machell's great-grandfather, who lost his arm at the battle of Bunker's Hill. Crackenthorpe was repurchased by the late Captain Machell from Lord Lonsdale in 1877. Mr. Machell's mother, who is still living and is resident in York, is a sister of the 8th Lord Middleton of Bridshail, Yorkshire. Born on the 5th December, 1862, Mr. Machell was educated at Clifton and Sand- hurst. He joined the 56th Regiment as lieu- tenant on 10th May, 1882, was promoted captain in October, 1888, temporary major in the Army, 1893, and retired (Reserve of Officers) in 1896. He served with the Mile expedition- ary Force in 1884-85, when he received medal with clasp and Bronze Star, and joined the Egyptian Army in 1886. He was present at the capture of Khormouan, 1888, and received the 4th class Osmanieh. He also took part in the operations round Suakin and the action of Femaizeh 1888 (horse shot), Sudan 1888-90-91, actin of Toski as Brigade Major No. 2 column, capture of Toffar (clasp on bronze star and 4th class Medjidieh). He commanded the 12th Sudanese Battalion, 1891-95, was Inspector General, Egyptian Coastguards, 1896, and was appointed Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior, 1898. He received the Grand Cordon of the Medjidieh in 1902.

div.head: CAIRO IMPROVEMENTS. THE GHEZIREH BRIDGE.
div.p: Another new bridge is to be built across the Nile, the Government having decided on the construction of a magnificent structure to unite Boulac and Ghezireh. The work will be taken in hand shortly.

The new bridge will be twenty metres in width and will form a most convenient connect- ing link between the centre of Cairo and the fashionable new suburb of Ghezireh by the Boulac avenue. The Ghezireh quarter will thus soon form an integral portion of the Capital, especially as a double line of tramway is to be laid across the river. The Ghezireh end of the bridge will be about two metres to the north of the Ghezireh Palace Hotel and will divide the estate of the Egyptian Hotels Company in two parts.

It is obvious that with the universal tend- ency of all great cities-Alexandria being on of the very few exceptions to the general rule- to extend, so far as concerns their fashionable quarters, in a westerly direction, Ghezireh is inevitably destined to become the "Champs Elysees" of the Capital of Egypt. The only drawback to the development of Ghezireh has been its distance from the centre of the city, but this will be now entirely obviated by the new bridge, which will bring it in direct communica- tion with the centre of Cairo.

div.head: THE GHIZEH WASH-OUT.
div.p: A telegram received from the Traffic Mana- ger, State Railways, states that transhipment of passengers at Abon el Noumros will cease from to-day, and trains will pass directly to the south.

div.head: PORT SAID CONSULATE.
div.p: The King has been graciously pleased to appoint Donald Andreas Cameron, Esq., to be his Majesty's Consul-General at Port Said, with jurisdiction over all the coast-line east of Damietta Light to El-Arish, the Suez Maritime Canal, the banks of the Canal, including the towns of Ismailia and Suez.

div.head: VARIOUS CREDITS.
div.p: The sum of L.E. 25,000 is to be spent during the next financial year on the Ghizeh reformatory school, L.E. 20,000 on the enlargement of the Abbassieh madhouse. Another credit of L.E. 10,000 is to be opened for the Technical School at Cairo and L.E. 40,000 will be expended on the new secondary schools which are to be built at Ghizeh and Abbassieh.

div.head: CAIRO WATER COMPANY.
div.p: The inauguration of the new artesian wells constructed by the Cairo Water Company at Rod el-Farag will take place about the end of December or the beginning of January, in the presence of H.H. the Khedive.
The company's new works at Boulac will be completed in a few months, when the Nile Cold Storage Company will transfer their machinery thereto.

div.head: GLOBE-TROTTER AT LUXOR. (From our Correspondent)
div.p: A.W. Crawford, the globe-trotter, has pass- ed by this town on his way to Khartoum and Abyssinia. In the latter place, he does not expect "much fun," as he expressed it.

This typical young American is well equip- ped for his tour, physically and mentally; for I see in him, a keen observer, a reasoning thinker and an excellent writer, besides that apparent coolness that characterises his nation. He will reach the United States, landing at San Francisco, in April, 1907. I certainly do wish him a happy and an interesting world- around trip.

div.head: NEW ROUTE TO ABYSSINIA.
div.p: It is stated by the "Temps" that a company has been formed in London to pen up com- mercially the river Jube, which separates British East Africa from Italian Somali land. A flotilla of tugs and barges is said to be in process of construction for the navigation of the river. The company is credited with the intention of linking the extreme point reached by their boat service with the Abyssinian capital by means of a caravan route which will compete with the Harrar Railway.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID. (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: On the evening of Wednesday a grand concert was given by the band from an Austrian first-class cruiser in the little garden adjoining the Eastern Exchange, in aid of the Austrian Benevolent Society of Port Said. The garden was magnificently decorated with flags of all nations. The band played 10 very select pieces and were twice encored. It is hoped that the society will be able to make a few homes com- fortable with the proceeds of this concert.
A big ball will be given at the Eastern Exchange on the 16th February in aid of our new Sporting Club.

div.head: THE SAMANOUD AFFAIR. TRUE VERSION OF INCIDENT.
div.p: As certain exaggerated statements have been published with regard to a disturbance at Sa- manoud, Gharbieh province, we are glad to be able to give the true account of the concurrence there, which we have from official sources.

It appears that on the morning of the 27th November, a telegram from a number of Copts and Europeans reached the moudirieh head- quarters, stating that a number of Muslims had insulted the Christian religion by holding a mock funeral, imitating the officiating priest and cross-bearer.

On enquiries being made it proved that seven men of the lowest class had insulted both Christian and Muslim religions. On the morn- ing of the 27th they entered the El Adawi- mosque, interrupted prayers, and created a great disturbance. After leaving the mosque they indulged in a travesty of a Christian funeral, and having insulted both religions found themselves pursued by the police.
five have been arrested and have confessed their guilt. The remaining members of the gang are the object of careful search.

div.head: BRITISH CONCULAR COURT. IMPORTANT DECISION.
div.p: The appeal of the defendant in the case of Major Nicol, of the Rifle Brigade, against a local firm of carriers and forwarding agents came on for bearing yesterday morning before Judge Cator at the British Consular Court in Cairo. Major Nicol had in the first in- stance recovered £131 damages in the lower Court for loss of goods pilfered from luggage which he had entrusted to the defendant firm to forward from Cairo to London. Against this decision the defendants appealed, but the judge dismissed the appeal with costs.

The case was made interesting by several points of public interest, amongst which was the fact that the plaintiff had insured his luggage against marine risks only and for a sum inferior to the amount of his claim.
Mr. Frederick Leveneaux, of Alexandria, appeared for Major Nicol and Dr. Sciortino, LLD., for the defendant firm of carriers.

div.head: BELGIAN CONSULATE.
div.p: The Belgian Government has appointed Mr. Rabyns de Schneidaner Acting Consul at Alex- andria. This gentleman was formerly at the Belgian Consulate at Smyrns. He is a consul "de carriere." Hitherto the Belgian Consulate at Alexandria has been occupied by an un- professional consul.

div.head: UM RUS OPERATIONS.
div.p: The progress report No. 58, for half-month ending Oct. 31st, gives the following par- ticulars of operations:

550 ft cross-out was advanced 9 ft, to a total distance of 70 ft. At 67 ft in a branch of quartz was out 4 ins wide, assaying 1 oz 3 dwts 5 grs per ton. 450-ft level north-east was extended 15 ft to a total of 107 ft, passing through dykes 4 and 5. Quartz at junction with dykes was 12 ins wide, assaying 3 dwts 22 grs per ton. 450-ft level south-west was driven 10 ft, total length 115 ft; the quartz averaged 11 ins wide, worth 4 dwts 3 grs per ton. 450-ft main winze was deepened 10 ft, making a total depth of 91 ft. Over this distance the vein average 20 ins wide and 16 dwts 3 grs per ton in value. 350-ft level north-east was advanced 4 ft, to a distance of 302 ft; suspended, Cross-out south-east at 300 ft was driven 10 ft; no discovery. 350 ft No. 2 winze north-east was deepened 10 ft, total depth 68 ft; in dyke No. 3 350 ft level south-west was extended 11 ft 6 ins to a total distance of 357 ft 6 ins. Vein averaged 19 ins wide and dwts per ton in value. 350-ft No. 2 winze south-west was sunk 10 ft, to a depth of 74 ft; in dyke No. 8. 245-ft level north-east was advanced 14 ft, total distance 251 ft. Quartz averaged 8 ins assay- ing a trace. In two stopes below this level the quartz is 21 ins wide, worth 1 oz 1 dwt 6 grs per ton. 245 south-west level was ad- vanced 5 ft, total distance 395 ft. Quartz, 8 ins wide, assayed a trace of gold per ton. In a stope below this level the quartz, 24 ins wide, is worth 7 dwts per ton. 245 No. 3 wings south-west was deepened 14 ft, total depth 115 ft. Quartz 12 ins wide, assayed a trace. Will shortly make connection with No. 3 level. Western shaft was sunk 4 ft; in granite. Total depth 252 ft. 75-ft level south-west was advanced 4ft to a distance of 147 ft. Quartz, 11 ins wide, assayed 7 dwts 13 grs per ton.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. FOOTBALL
div.p: The meeting of the Railway Institute F.C. and F. Co. of the K.R.R. on Tuesday, proved to be a capital game. The slight rain which fell in the forenoon had no effect on the ground,- if anything it improved it. The railway men's full team turned out to opposed their antagon- ists. From the very start off and all through the first half the home team were the superior XI., and they were continually attacking the visitors' custodian. The consequence was, that when the first half terminated, the railway men had 5 goals to their credit. In the second half F. Co. struggled with the desperate energy, and by the 'cute understanding of the left wing pair, managed to score a couple of goals. Thus the Railway Institute were left the victors by 5 goals to 2. Mr. Allport was the referee.

div.head: SOCIETE KHEDIVIALE DE GEOGRAPHIE
div.p: Le commandant C. Lemaire, du 2e regiment d'artilerie belge, vient d'envoyer a la Societe Khedivial de Geographie la collection de ses nombreuses publications, relative a ses explo- rations au Congo. Ce brillant officer se dis- tingne par son activite et les services qu'il a deja rendu a la science le mettent au premier rang des voyageurs acientifiques. Parmi les travaux qu'il nous a envoyes nons devons signaler la magistrale "Mission Scientifique du Katanga" en 16 memoires, splendide publica- tion in 4, enrichie de magnifiques dessins, photographies et aquarelles, qui permettent de suivre des yeux l'explorateur dans ses pere- grinations. Les memoires, ou volumes, con- tiennent le journal de route et les resultats des observations astronomiques, magnetiques et altimetriques effectnees sur les territoires qu'il a traverses du 4 Aout 1898 au 2 Septembre 1900.
L'ouvrage est accompagne d'une grande carte du Katangra au 100,000eme et de 30 feuilles (des 130 qui composent la meme Carte) au 50.000eme.
Comme on le voit, il a'agit d'un travail fou- damental, honore d'une preface d'Elisee Reclus.

Le Commandant Lemaire, sera parmi nous, de retour du Congo, en Janvier et nous savons que sur les instances de la Societe et de ses amis, il a consenti a donner une conference au Caire sur ses voyages. Cette conference sera agremantee de projections.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTELS.
div.p: Nous publions d'antre part le prospectus relatif a l'emission publique des actions de "The National Hotels & Residence Company" dont la souscription sera ouverte a l'Anglo- Egyptian Bank les lundi 4 et Mardi 5 Decem- bre courant.

Nous avons deja eu l'occasion d'entretenir nos lecteurs de cette affaire, lors de l'inaugu- ration du "National Hotel" dont la nouvelle compagnie est devenue proprietaire; nous ne nous etendrons donc plus aur la description de cet etablissement.
Par contre, que'ques mots ne seront pas superflus au sujet du Grand Hotel et Casino d'Ain-Sofar, que la compagnie a egalement achete.

Ain-Sofar, situe dans la partie la plus belle et la plus saine du Liban a une altitude de 1,350 metre, est deja actuellement la ville- giature estivale de nombre d'Egyptians, et il est certain que bien des Europaens desireux de se reposer des fatigues de notre climat sesont heureux d'aller y respirer l'air frais et vivifiant de la montagne, plutot que de faire le voyage long et couteux d'Europe; Aiu-Aofar n'est en effet qu'a 24 heures de l'Egypte.

C'est an aurplus une fort heureuse ides qu'a la Societe d'exploiter en meme temps des Hotels en Egypt et en Syris, ce qui lui per- mettra avec un personnel a pierne superieur a celui qui serait necessaire a l'un des etalibes- ments, de mener de front les deux, vu qu'ils ne seront respentivement en pleine activite qu'en des saisons differentes.

L'emission de la "N. H. & R. C." nous paralt au demeurant ne pouvoir etre qu'un succes. Toutes les affaires d'hotels montes dans ce pays ont donne des resultats brillants, et leurs actions sont cotees actuellement pour la p'upart, a 250% de leur valeur nominale; pourquoi n'en serait-il pas de meme pour la "National" qui n'a pas pour seul but de cher- cher a creer des affaires nouvelles, mais offre a ses actionnaires d'importants etablissements en pleine exploitation.

div.head: BOURSE DU CAIRE
div.p: Caire, la ler Decembre
Le marche a ete certainement meilleur qu'on ne l'esperait.
Non seulement la baissa de Londres n'a pas ete suivie, mais il y a eu pendent un momnet un mouvement qui semblait etre le precurseur d'une reprise.

Ainsi la National Bank que l'Exchange cotait 25 a eu des acheteurs aux environs de 25 1/4 pour l'ancienne et 24 7/8 pour la nou- velle. C'est du reste a ce prix que la bourse de Londres a pratique aujourd'hui.
L'agricultural Bank a fait 9 3/16; elle cote 9 3/8 en Europe - c'est une smeliora- tions sensible.
Le Credit Foncier Egyptian demeure station- naire aux environs de 780 Frs. ; une avance rapide ne nous etonnerait pas, le cap de la liquidation ayant ete facilement franchi.
Le marche a ete bon pour les Egyptian Estates; les titres changent de main dans d'excellentes conditions pour les acheteurs; la premiere occasion servira la hanses.
Les Nungovich Hotels ont oscille entre 10 1/2 et 10 7/16; on les a reclames a terme mais les vendeurs monquent.
Les Baehler ontavance d'un huitienne environ et les Upper ont enragistre 5 3/16.
Le saison commence bien, les touristes ar- riveut plus tot que l'annee derniere; personne ne s'en plaindre.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (aujourd'hui a midi et demie)
Le marche est en general assex soutenu mais peu brillent comme affaires.

La Banque Nationale flechit a 24 3/4, la Ban- que d'Athenes a 136 1/2, la Banque d'Abyssinie a 7, la Delta Land a 2 3/16. l'Urbaine a 5, la Crown Brewery a 205, les Markets a 26/3, la Salt and Soda a 21/3, et l'Alexandria Water a 14 1/2.
Comme on le voit pas les chiffres ci-dessurs les petites valeuqs perdent de nouveau da terrain, a l'exception des Estates qui sont fereus a 1 3/8.
Eu hausse l'Obligation Foncier reown a 315 1/2. l'Agrisule a 9 7/38, la Cssa de ecoute a 210 1/2, les Bachles a 2 15/16, la Ramleh Rad- way a 6 15/16, et les Privilegiees Tramways a 155 1/2.

div.head: IRRIGATION ENGINEERING.
div.docAuthor: By Sir Handury Brown, K.C.M.G., late Inspector-General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, and formly in Upper Egypt.
div.head: VI.
div.p: The preceding articles have dealt with the considerations which affect the designing of a canal projet. After the designing comes con- struction, and after construction the use of the works to serve the end for which they were designed and constructed. To one class of engineers the construction period is the only one that is interesting; and, no doubt, the satisfaction of seeing an important work grown under one's hands is a solid one. Moreover, the "gallery" applauds, and honors are distributed when a work of suffi- cient importance to attract the attention of the public is successfully brough to a comple- tion; and there is satisfaction also in that, though not so solic. All the world, for instance, has heard of the Assonouan dam, though many have very inaccurate ideas as to whom should be given the credit of the original conception of the design and of the actual construction. But the dam is there, whoever fathered it, and it is doing its duty , regarding which little will be known by any but those who are specially in- terested in Egypt and watch its further develop- ment. Fortunate, indeed, is the engineer whose duties comprehend the work of each of the three period of design, construction and administra- tion, and who has the satisfaction of converting his design into material structures, and of using them to produce prosperity among the people for whose benefit they were designed.

Already, in the first article, a list has been given of the different descriptions of works that an irrigation engineer has to design, con- struct and utilise. They are many and various. The ordinary principles and methods of con- struction apply to most of them. But from among them there may be selected as belonging peculiarly to the province of the irrigation engineer such masonry works as high dams to create storage reservoirs, anicuts and barrages to raise the summer level of rivers, canal head- works to control the main supply; also syphons, aqueducts, super-passages, to carry one watercourse past another; and lastly navigation locks. Most of these would have their founda- tion level below the lowest water level, and would present more or less difficulty of con- struction according to the nature of the foundation bed and the strength of springs over the foundation area. The ordinary method of getting in the foundations is to surround the area of operations by banks to exclude the outside water, and to get rid of the inside water by pumping. The concrete is then laid, so to speak, "in the dry," an expression not to be understood literally, as where springs are working the conrete may have to be laid in about a foot of water. This was the method of construction adopted in the case of the Assiout barrage, lately built in Upper Egypt simultane- ously with the Assouan dam. The advantage of this method over others is that all the work done is in sight at the time of execution. But it has this disadvantage- that, unless the springs are intelligently and skilfully treated defects in the floor will be created by the water forcing its way either under or through the floor. It happens sometimes that the super- vising staff has not the experience necessary for successfully dealing with the springs, but gains it as the work proceeds, so that the first season's work is not without its mistakes. The principle to be observed in dealing with springs is that no attempt should be made to stop them working until they have been surrounded on all sides by masonry of sufficient strength to resisit the efforts of the spring to find a new outlet through it. If the cement concrete, which forms the bottom layer of the foundation platform, is advanced from one extremity of the work in an even line towards the other, the springs will form runs for themselves through the unset edge of the concrete layer. And, as it advances, more and more springs will assert themselves in the same way, until there is a strong outflow along the advancing edge of the concrete, due to the combined action of all the springs, except such as have forced their way sideways to the margins of the concrete layer; where they will continue to work. The cementing material of the con- crete will thus be washed away as soon as it is laid and runs will thus be formed under and through the foundation platform, which will give trouble afterwards. The way to avoid this is carefully to locate all springs, and, as the concrete advances, to carry it all round them, but not over them. As the springs will continue to work, their water must be led away in pipes, or chan- nels al set masonry, over or through the con- crete layers, until they are completely surroun- ded by masonry too strong for them to burst through. They can then be forcibly stopped with safety, and they will be powerless to work
harm. The methods of dealing with springs vary in detail with the ingenuity of those in charge of the work, but the guiding principle is the same with all, namely to attempt no violence to the spring till sufficient forces are marshalled all round it to compel submission.

The disadvantages of putting in foundations with strong springs in action over the founda- tion bed have caused other methods to be resorted to. In India the method of getting in foundations by well-sinking is in favor, and has repeatedly been employed with much success. Circular or rectangular wells are built on well- curbs which rest on the sand at the natural water-level, or at the level to which it may be judged convenient to lower the water by pumping. The wells are weighted, and the sand excavated from within by special plant, so that the wells sink below water level as the excavation continues. More height is added to them and teh sinking is conti- nued till the bottom of the well has reached the required depth. The superstructure is afterwards built on a platform covering the wells.

There is also the method of getting in foundations by the help of compressed air. which, however, has not been much used in irrigation work in India or Egypt. It requires special plant and labour skilled in the pro- cess, as there are dangers attending its em- polyment by untrained hands.

div.head: MARRIAGE STILL POPULAR.
div.p: Dr. Prinzing, of Berlin, denies that the number of bachelors and old maids is increas- ing in Europe. As a matter of fact, says the "Daily Telegraph," he states that marriage is decreasing only in Sweden, France, and Ireland. In Germany the number of bachelors steadily decreases, and only in certain limited areas can any increase of old maids be found.

div.head: TAXATION OF MONTE CARLO.
div.p: Monte Carlo has just put in force a most important scheme to tax all foreigners engaged in business in the principality. A large num- ber of licences granted during the summer are being held back. If the new rule is made retrospective it will affect all English limited liability companies, besides a large number of English, French, Italian, and German mer- chants and shopkeepers. Villa holders may also be liable to taxation.

ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING to be held at Winsheter House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C., on Thursday, 21st December, 1905, at 3 p.m. o'clock precisely.

Notice is hereby given that the annual ordinary general meeting of the company will be held in Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad Street in the City of London, on Thursday, 21st December, 1905, at 3 p.m. o'clock precisely, for the purpose of receiving the Directors' Report and Balance Sheet for the period ended 30th September, 1905, electing Directors in the place of the three retiring by rotation, appointing auditors for the ensuing year and fixing remuneration, declaring a dividend, and transacting the Ordinary General Business of the Company, and also for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit, passing the following Resolution then intended to be proposed, that is to say:-

That, in pursuance of Article 44 of the Statutes of the Metropolitan and Cairo-Helouan Railway, and in view of the recommendation of the Conseil d'Administration, that a sum of L.E. 2,412,780 out of the profits of the Metropolitan and Cairo-Helouan Railway for the year ending 31st December 1904, be placed to special Reserve Fund.
div.docAuthor: By order of the Board, E.J. Borne, Secretary. 214, Gresham House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C.

div.p: N.B.- Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer, and whose names are not on the Share Registers of the Company, are reminded that if they wish to attend this General Meeting of the Company, they must first deposit their Bearer Warrants, together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses, at the Registered Offices of the Company in London two clear days before the date of the General Meeting, viz., not later than the 18th December, 1905. The Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held. Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, which must be produced by the Holders attending the Meeting.

The Directors have to report that in consequence of the extension of the Company's system by the construction of new lines, and by the absorption of other railway companies, the work entailed in preparing the Accounts has so increased as to render it impossible to prepare the Balance Sheet and Revenue Accounts in time to complete the Audit and the Directors' Report for the Annual General Meeting, which, in conformity with the Companies Acts, must be held during 1905. It is therefore the intention of the Directors, at the General Meeting, which this notice convenes, to submit a formal resolution of adjournment of the Meeting until 30th January, 1906, at hich adjournment the business referred to on the Notice will be transacted.

In view of the above, and as the present Financial Year of the Company closes during the busiest season of the year, it is considered necessary to alter the date of closing from 30th September to 31st March. A Half-Yearly Report and Statement of Accounts will therefore be issued in 1906 as at 31st March, after which they will be issued annually.
div.docAuthor: By order of the Board, F.J. Horne, Secretary. 214, Gresham House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C.

TO ALL TO WHOM THESE PRESENTS SHALL COME I ALBERT BIRMINGHAM-MILLER of Calcutta in Bengal East Indies Barrister-at-Law and Official Assignee of the Court for the Relief of Insolvent Debtors at Calcutta aforesaid SEND GREETING WHERE AS on the thirty-first day of October One thousand nine hundred and five Isaac Shrager and Adolphe Shrager both of No. 28 Dalhousie Square Calcutta aforesaid the two members then resident in Calcutta aforesaid of the Mercantile firm of Shrager Brothers then carrying on business at amongst other places Calcutta aforesaid petitioned the said Court for the benefit of the previsions of Act 11 and 12 Victoria Chapter XXI (The Indian Insolvent Act) and by an order of the said Court made on the said petition and on the same day the real and personal estate of the said Petitioners was vested in me as such Official Assignee as aforesaid AND WHEREAS the Petitioners' said form of Shrager Brothers at the date of the said order was also carrying on business at London, Alexandria, Colombo, Singapore and Broome Western Australia and I am desirous of Appointing Attorneys of an Attorney to represent me in each of the said places last mentioned NOW THESE PRESENTS WITNESS that I am hereby constitute and appoint CAREL WILLEM DRECKMEIER of Alexandria Egypt Merchant, born in Amsterdam (Holland) on the twelfth day of April One thousand eight hundred seventy six, to be my tru and lawful Attorney to ask for demand bring to account and reckoning recover without legal process and receive all monies debts dues goods wares merchandise chattels effects and things whatsoever due or hereafter to be due owing and payable or belonging to the estates of the said Isaac Shrager and Adolphe Shrager or either of them as partners in the said firm of Shrager Brother at Alexandria aforesaid and by virtue of the said order now vested in me as such Assignee as aforesaid of the said estates by any ways or means or in any manner howsoever and upon receipt thereof or of any part thereof to sign seal and execute or make and give good and sufficient releases receipts or discharges for the same.

To receive possession and charge of all cargoes consignments merchandise property and effects of every description now or hereafter belonging or consigned to the said two Insolvents of either of them or to the said firm of Shrager Brothers at Alexandria aforesaid and to act in reference thereto according to the usual course of business and to give all necessary orders instructions and directions with regard thereto.

To receive to my use all sums of money due and to become due to the said two Insolvents under or by virtue of any bonds contracts charter parties shippign orders Bills of Lading Bills of Exchange Hoonees cheques or other deeds or securities of any kind of description in the premises as the case may be and upon receipt thereof or of any part thereof to endorse the same and to make sign and deliver sufficient receipts and discharges.

AND I hereby as such Official Assignee and Assignee as aforesaid agree to ratify and confirm all and whatsoever my said Attorney or his substitutes or substitute shall do or legally cause to be done in the premises.
IN WITNESS thereof I the said Albert Birmingham Miller have hereunto set my hand and seal this fourth day of November One thousand nine hundred and five.

Signed, Sealed and delivered by the said Albert Birmingham Miller, Offical Assignee at Calcutta, aforesaid in the presence of A.B. Miller, Official Assignee of Bengal. C.W. Foley, Solicitor and Motary Public, Calcutta.

div.head: (From our own Correspondent).
div.p: I find it hard to see the exact reason of all the pother of "resignation" and "dissolution" that has come about. The ordinary course of events might well have entailed a dissolution early in next session. What has happened to hasten that course of precipitate a "crisis"? Mr. Chamberlain has enunciated no views that he was not well known to entertain, nor does there seem any crying need for instant action that would be distrubing to many and agreeable to few. All politics are constantly on the knees of the gods, and all things are possible. But, judging by such signs as are plain to see, many thoughts that occupy many minds may by the offspring of prolific Father Wish.

A movement is on foot among leading men in Great Britain and Germany to promote a better understanding between the two countries. A committee has been formed, and a meeting is arranged to take place next week at Westminster, at which Lord Avebury will preside. Amongst those who have signified their intention of being present are the Bishop of Southwark, Lord Stanmore, Sir Michael Foster, Sir Ernest Tritton, M.P., Sir John Kennaway, M.P., and the Rev. Dr. Horton, President of the Free Church Counsil. An address expressing the desire for a more cordial feeling between the two nations has been signed by a number of influential gentlemen. Similar action taken by public men in Germany is being equally well supported.

It seems more like centuries than years since we have been groaning under the "made in Germany," "made in Holland," "made in Austria" labels. And what was at first a fund of Jocosity for the self confessedly comic papers has long been diagnosed as a grave peril to trade, industry, and employment. This, then, is an auspicious moment for the birth of that "British-made League," to which I offer me best wishes for success. The name of the League explains its ideals and activities. It is actuated by the large hope of gaining the support of so many people as to enable it to regain employment for the thousands who are now workless, owing to foreign competition in articles which could be made at home.

Apart from other uses of the Motor-car Exhibition just opened at Olympia, it has served once more to emphasise the remarkable progression- geometrical rather than arithmetical- of this great industry. As Mr. Arthur Stanley pointed out, the cars now running in the United Kingdom represent a value of some fifteen millions sterling, and the prospects for the future promise a more than proportionate increase. The motor-car has now served its probabtion, and the time has surely come when its interests should receive full, if not the first, consideration upon our roads and highways. And the chief point for attention here is that of the upkeep of the roads, the condition of which affects the mechanical so muh more than the horse-drawn vehicle. Mr. Stanley suggests, nor is he alone in the idea, the need of a central board of some kind to supervise all the roads of the kingdom. The £1,800,000 now being spent in this direction, if supplemented by the income derived from motor fines and licences, would be fully sufficient to provide the necessary funds. And the prospect of broad, level, dustless highways on all the chief routes is a dream not only attractive but quite possible of realisation.

The magnificent pile of buildings erected on what was known as the Carrington House site, opposite the Admirality and Horse Guards, in which to house the aggregation of military and administrative departments that comprise the War Office, is rapidly approaching completion, and it is hoped that by midsummer of next year the whole of the sections, several of which at present outlie the dingy premises in Pall Mall, will have been transferred to Whitehall.

The removal of the hoarding and scaffolding the previously obscured the view of the new building on each of its four sides has revealed a pile that is in every way worthy of its unique position in one of the most remarkable and best known thoroughfares in Europe. The design not only accords with its surroundings, but is appropriate to the purpose for which the building has been erected. Years have passed out of recollection since the premises numbered 80 to 93, Pall Mall, housed all the headquarter departments of the Army, and it will be a great convenience to those charged with the administration of the War
Office when all its business comes to be transacted under one roof.

I sincerely hope the movement we are promised in London for the erection of "skyscrapers" will not be initiated. New York and other American towns are made hideous by these huge steel erections, which would destroy all the charm of London. The idea of "office towers" about the height of the campanile of the Westminster Roman Catholic Cathedral is simply detestable, and I trust that a vigorous resistance will be offered to any proposals to amend the building laws so as to permit their erection.

The sinking of the L. and S.-W. steamer Hilda and the burning of the model lodging-house in Glasglow are both remarkable among the defeats inflicted upon humanity by the elements, because help was apparently so near. The rocks upon which the unfortunate vessel struck are only a few cables' length from St. Malo, while the Central Fire Station of Glasglow is only five hundred yards away from the scene of the fire by which thirty-nine people lost their lives. It might have been supposed that in both cases help would have come in ample time to save life, but in the first disaster the weather prevented the people in St. Malo from knowning anything of what had happened until it was too late; while in the second, though the alarm was given at once, not even the prompt energy of the Glasglow Fire Brigade could neutralise the start which the fire had obtained. People are horrified by such tragedies, but I believe it is rather the drama in them that appals than the actual loss of llife. We are all instinctly moved to the very depths of our being by the thought of the suddenness and the extent of these calamities, because we can picture to ourselves the terror of the scene.

But a rise in the death-rate inplying the loss of ten times as many lives as were claimed by sea and fire in these two recent catastrophe would, probably, pass unnoticed save by a few statisticians. Even had the same loss of life been caused in the same ways it would have given the average man very little distress if it had been spread over a week or fortnight, and had it happened in some distant part of the world to people of another race, he would scarcely have noticed it at all. In such cases the dramatic element is wanting, and therefore sympathy is not aroused. It may be a sad fact to have to acknowledge, but to deny that it is a fact would be absurd.

At last the "All Blacks" have met their match. Although the New Zealanders won on the posrt at Inverlieth on Saturday, the game throughout was of the most even character, and up to ten minutes before time Scotland was leading. How far the result was affected by the disablement at this point of the Scottish wing forward, which caused the New Zealanders to be reprimanded for deliberately rough play, it is not easy to decide. But the fact remains that it was a battle on absolutely equal terms. All honor to Scotland, which has demonstrated the possibility and established the precedent. May it speedily be followed, and may the narrow margin of victory fall next time upon the other side!

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: (From our Correspondent).
Major E.R.O. Ludlow, Army Service Corps, the D.A.A. and Q.M.G. at Alexandria, has been promoted to the rank of lieutenant-colonel. Congratulations.

Another promoation in the same corps and in the same command is that of Brevet-Major A.E. Delavoye to substantive field rank. Major Delavoye gets his majority at a little over fifteen years' service. He was formerly in the Suffolk Regiment, and was in the operations in the Sudan, 1898, for which he wears the medal and the Khedive's medal, and as a D.A.A.G. on the staff he earned his brevet step in the South African War.

Major R.S. Oxley, King's Royal Rifle Corps, has been appointed second in command of the 1st Battalion at Cairo, from the 2nd Battalion in India. Major Oxley has the Manipore Expedition of 1891 (medal with clasp) to his credit.
Maqjor Hickman, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, on joining the 1st Battalion, has been granted leave from the 7th prox. to the 31st on private affairs.
The 4th Battalion Rifle Brigade arrived at Malta on the 16th inst. from Catham, England, per the S.S. Assaye, for service in that garrison.

During the adbsence of the cruiser Leviathan, now homeward bound for re-commissioning, Rear-Admiral the Hon. Hedworth Lambtom, commanding the Third Cruiser Squadrom, will fly his flag on the cruiser Carnarvon.

The visit of the Atlantic Fleet to the Balearic Isaldn has been cancelled in order to let the ships home to port as early as possible in December for Christmas and New Year leave. The battleships and cruisers will have a speed trial run home from Gibraltar.
The new enlarged naval target has given the most satisfactory results. It is more accurate in recording hits and its improved rigging prevents it being shot away.

Two years ago, when the formation of a British North Sea Squadrom was motted, the German Press went into a paroxysm of fury, and denounced the plan as a direct menace to Germany's naval power and expansion, despite the fact that Germany was forming a small but compact battle squadron for service in the shallow waters of that sea. There is every reason to believe that the formation of the squadron, delayed by the redistribution of our naval forces at home and abroad, will be ultimately proceeded with. The material is to hand in the group of shallow draught battleships of the Canopus class, six in number: Canopus, Albion, Vangeance, Glory, Goliath, and Ocean. They have displacement of 12,950 tons, a speed of 18 ¼ knots, and they carry crews of 750 officers and men, and an armament of four 12-inch 46-ton guns, twelve 6-inch guns, twelve 12-pounders, six 3-pounders, and the usual machine gun and torpedo equipment. Their comparatively shallow draught of 26 feet makes them very suitable for manoeuvring in shallow waters off the coasts of the North Sea. They are amply protected by armour belts on the water line, and the barbettes and other guns positions are heavily armoured. The six form a formidable suadron.

div.head: IN HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S CONSULAR COURT AT CAIRO.
div.p: Probate Jurisdiction.
In the Goods of Eliza Rogers late of No. 11 Sharia Gama Cherkess Cairo and of the Ghizeh Farm Dairy, Spinster, Deceased.

NOTICE is hereby given pursuant to the statute 22 and 23 Victoria chapter 35, that all persons claiming to be Creditors, or otherwise to have any claims or demands affecting the Esatte of the above Deceased, who died on the 24th of April 1905 at No. 11 Sharia Gama Cherkess Cairo, are hereby required on or before the 31st day of December 1905 to furnish in writing the particulars of such claims or demands to the undersigned, Agent for Arthur Sansome Preston the attorney of Mary Rogers a next of kin of the Deceased to whom lettters of Administration of the personal estate and effects of the said Deceased were granted by H.B.M. Consular Court at Cairo upon the 2nd day of August 1905, and Notice is hereby further given that after the said 31st day of December 1905 the said Administrator will proceed to distribute the assets of the said Deceased, having regard only to the claims and demands of which particulars shall have been given as above required.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: La Societe a pour principal objet l'exploitation du National Hotel, de la National Residence recemment creed au Caire et du Grand Hotel de Sofar, a Alu-Sofar (Mont-Liban), que la Societe a acheter.

Le National Hotel nouvellement construit au quartier Ismailieh a ete inaugure ces jours derniers. Il est deja en pleine exploitation et l'on peut esperer, d'apres les arrangements conlcus, qu'il sera plein du 15 Decembre au 31 Mars. La Direction eu a ete confide a M. Ch. Bauer, dont la longue experience l'a recommende particulierement au choix des Administrateurs.

La National Residence, annexe de l'Hotel, compend des appartements meubles composes de chambres, salons, cabinets de toilette etc., loues a l'annee. Les contrats passes a ce jour assureut un revenu considerable pour l'annee, revenu qui sera augmente du chiffre des locations encore a conclure.
Le National Hotel et la National Residence seront ouverts toute l'annee.
En ete la direction et une partie du personnel du National Hotel se transporteront au Grand Hotel de Sofar.

Cette station sitnee a 1350 metres d'altitude dans le Mont-Liban est pour ainsi dire aussi populaire en Egypte qu'en Syrie. Chaque annee les Egyptians s'y rendeut, pendant la saison, en nombre toujours plus grand; c'est aussi le rendez-vous de toutes les notabilite des regions avoisinantes.

Le Grand Hotel de Sofar et le Casino diriges jusqu'ini par des personnes sans expe- rience rapportaient neamoins un revenu annuel de 20 a 25%. Eutre les mains de la Societe cette entreprise est appelee au plus grand avenir.

La Soceite a'efforcers egalement de doter la localite des attractions qui pourront lui attirer une plus nombreuse clientele. On vient de decouvrer une nouvelle source d'eau ferrugineuse et la constuction d'un etablissement thermal est a l'etude.
Des arrangement out ete faita pour facilitier le voyage aux residents egyptiens. Grace aux accords conclus on pourra dorenavant, se reudre du Caire a Ain Sofar en 24 heures, sans arret a Beyrouth.
On peut se procurer le Prospectus et le Bulletin de Souscription a l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Caire et a Alexandrie.
